slide.title: EUS-guided Gallbladder drainage
slide.text:
EUS-guided Gallbladder drainage Asian EUS summit 2016
Seoul National University College of Medicine Seoul National University Bundang Hospital
Jaihwan Kim

slide.title: Contents
slide.text:
Contents Background Brief history Indications Techniques Outcomes Summary & conclusions
2

slide.title: Background
slide.text:
Background Acute cholecystitis Common disease in practice 6th most common GI diagnosis in ER in US
Treatment Surgical cholecystectomy Laparoscopic vs. Open Gallbladder drainage Inappropriate candidate for cholecystectomy Elderly Heavily comorbidities or advanced malignancy
Peery AF, et al. Gastroenterology 2015;149:1731-1741 e3 3

slide.title: Background
slide.text:
Background Percutaneous transhepatic gallbladder drainage (PTGBD) Most commonly used alternative Easy, effective & highly successful 56-100% Especially, temporary indwelling Adverse events Spontaneous tube removal Tractitis and subcutaneous infection Bleeding and fistula Tract seeding and bile peritonitis Recurrence
AE as high as 14% 4

slide.title: Background
slide.text:
Background Endoscopic transpapillary gallbladder drainage (ETGBD) 80-100% of success rate in recent studies
Technically not easy Still challenging in some cases Malignant cystic duct obstruction Previous metal stent insertion state Choi JH, et al. Gastrointest Interv 2013;2:30-35 Kedia P, et al. GIE 2015;82:1031-1036 5

slide.title: Background
slide.text: Background Endoscopic ultrasound guided gallbladder drainage (EUS-GBD) Technically evolved from experiences of extraluminal fluid accumulation (pseudocyst) drainage 6

slide.title: Contents
slide.text:
Contents Background Brief history Indications Techniques Outcomes Summary & conclusions
7

slide.title: Brief history
slide.text: Brief history First reports (2007) Baron TH, et al. GIE 2007;65:735-737 Kwan V, et al. GIE 2007;66:582-586 Lee SS, et al. GIE 2007;66:1008-1012 8

slide.title: Brief history
slide.text: Brief history Plastic stent or drainage tube 9 Choi JH, et al. GIE In press

slide.title: Brief history
slide.text: Brief history Covered metal stent (2011) Jang JW, et al. GIE 2011;74:176-181 10

slide.title: Brief history
slide.text: Brief history Lumen-apposing covered metal stent (2013) de la Serna-Higuera C, et al. GIE 2013;77:303-308 Itoi T, et al. Dig Endosc 2013;25 suppl 2:137-141 11

slide.title: Brief history
slide.text: Brief history New lumen-apposing stent (2014) Moon JH, et al. GIE 2014;79:990-995 12

slide.title: Brief history
slide.text: Brief history Single step lumen-apposing stent using a cautery-tipped stent (2014) Teoh AY, et al. GIE 2014;80:1171 13

slide.title: Brief history
slide.text: Brief history cSEMS or LAMS 14 Choi JH, et al. GIE In press

slide.title: Contents
slide.text:
Contents Background Brief history Indications Techniques Outcomes Summary & conclusions
15

slide.title: Indications
slide.text: Indications Not established Suggested indication Widmer J, et al. Dig Endosc 2014;26:525-531 Choi JH, et al. Dig Endosc 2015;27:1-7 16

slide.title: Indications
slide.text:
Indications
Possible indications Bridge to surgery Patients with critically ill patients Inappropriate candidate for PTGBD Patients with surgically altered anatomy
17

slide.title: Contents
slide.text:
Contents Background Brief history Indications Techniques Outcomes Summary & conclusions
18

slide.title: Techniques
slide.text:
Techniques
Visualization of gallbladder Prepyloric antrum vs. Duodenal bulb GB neck Less mobile and less likely to move away from duodenal wall
Closest site to the bowel Identification of interposing vessels Choi JH, et al. Dig Endosc 2015;27:1-7 19

slide.title: Techniques
slide.text:
Techniques
Puncture 19 gauge FNA needle 0.035 or 0.025 inch hydrophilic guidewire Dilatation Cautery 6 or 10 Fr Cystotome Needle knife Non-cautery Soehendra biliary dilator up to 8 Fr Balloon dilator
20

slide.title: Techniques
slide.text: Techniques Stent or drainage catheter 5 to 8.5 Fr pigtail type catheter 7 to 10 Fr double pigtail plastic stent Covered self-expandable metallic stent (cSEMS) Lumen- apposing metal stents (LAMS) 21

slide.title: Contents
slide.text:
Contents Background Brief history Indications Techniques Outcomes Summary & conclusions
22

slide.title: Outcomes
slide.text: Outcomes Choi JH, et al. GIE In press 23

slide.title: Outcomes
slide.text:
Outcomes
Summary of published data (Jan 2007 to Jul 2015) Technical success rate 96.48% (192/199) Clinical success rate 95.48% (190/199) Choi JH, et al. GIE In press 24

slide.title: Outcomes
slide.text: Outcomes Adverse events (33/199, 16.6%) Pain after procedure Stent migration Fever Pancreatitis Bleeding Perforation or pneumoperitoneum Sepsis Mostly recovered with conservative management Choi JH, et al. GIE In press 25

slide.title: Outcomes
slide.text: Outcomes International multicenter study Kahaleh M et al. Dig Liv Dis 2016;48:1054-1057 26

slide.title: Outcomes
slide.text: Outcomes Long term outcomes 56 patients for median 275 days (40-1185 days) Median stent patency 190 days (15-1185 days) Cumulative stent patency 86% at 3 years 54 patients had no recurrence Late adverse events in 4 patients (7.1%) Stent migration (2) & acute cholecystitis d/t occlusion (2) Choi JH, et al. Endoscopy 2014;46:656-661 27

slide.title: Outcomes
slide.text: Outcomes EUS-GBD vs PTGBD Jang JW, et al. Gastroenterology 2012;142:805-811 28

slide.title: Outcomes
slide.text: Outcomes EUS-GBD vs PTGBD in patients with malignant cystic duct obstruction Choi JH, et al. GIE In press 85.7% 78.6% 100% 86.4% 29

slide.title: Outcomes
slide.text: Outcomes Hospital stays and medical costs Choi JH, et al. GIE In press 30

slide.title: Outcomes
slide.text:
Outcomes Long stent patency Average 130 days
Choi JH, et al. GIE In press 31

slide.title: Outcomes
slide.notes: In contrast, placement of a LAMS in patients with an indwelling percutaneous drain offers more technical challenges. This is partly because of decompression of the gallbladder, which limits endosonographic visualization; coiling of the guidewire within a smaller gallbladder; transmural tract creation; and LAMS deployment. In addition, a thick-walled, fibrotic gallbladder may be encountered in patients with chronic cholecystitis making it difficult to pass dilating balloons and electrocautery devices without causing a separation between the gallbladder and gastrointestinal tract. Indeed, because of the limited mechanical advantage of passing cautery devices and/or balloon dilators through the gallbladder wall we resorted to grasping the endoscopically placed guidewire from within the gallbladder using forceps passed through the percutaneous tract in 2 patients (via a cholangioscope in 1). Subsequent traction on both ends of the guidewire markedly improved mechanical advantage, and also eliminated the possibility of guidewire loss. A LAMS mounted onto a cautery-tipped delivery system has recently gained Food and Drug Administration approval. This device modification could greatly simplify EUS-guided transmural LAMS placement.
slide.notesNormalized: in contrast, placement of a lams in patients with an indwelling percutaneous drain offers more technical challenges. this is partly because of decompression of the gallbladder, which limits endosonographic visualization; coiling of the guidewire within a smaller gallbladder; transmural tract creation; and lams deployment. in addition, a thick-walled, fibrotic gallbladder may be encountered in patients with chronic cholecystitis making it difficult to pass dilating balloons and electrocautery devices without causing a separation between the gallbladder and gastrointestinal tract. indeed, because of the limited mechanical advantage of passing cautery devices and/or balloon dilators through the gallbladder wall we resorted to grasping the endoscopically placed guidewire from within the gallbladder using forceps passed through the percutaneous tract in 2 patients (via a cholangioscope in 1). subsequent traction on both ends of the guidewire markedly improved mechanical advantage, and also eliminated the possibility of guidewire loss. a lams mounted onto a cautery-tipped delivery system has recently gained food and drug administration approval. this device modification could greatly simplify eus-guided transmural lams placement.
slide.notesHtml:
In contrast, placement of a LAMS in patients with an

indwelling percutaneous drain offers more technical

challenges. This is partly because of decompression of

the gallbladder, which limits endosonographic visualization;

coiling of the guidewire within a smaller gallbladder;

transmural tract creation; and LAMS deployment. In

addition, a thick-walled, fibrotic gallbladder may be

encountered in patients with chronic cholecystitis making

it difficult to pass dilating balloons and electrocautery

devices without causing a separation between the gallbladder

and gastrointestinal tract. Indeed, because of the

limited mechanical advantage of passing cautery devices

and/or balloon dilators through the gallbladder wall

we resorted to grasping the endoscopically placed

guidewire from within the gallbladder using forceps

passed through the percutaneous tract in 2 patients (via a

cholangioscope in 1). Subsequent traction on both ends

of the guidewire markedly improved mechanical advantage,

and also eliminated the possibility of guidewire loss.

A LAMS mounted onto a cautery-tipped delivery system

has recently gained Food and Drug Administration

approval. This device modification could greatly simplify

EUS-guided transmural LAMS placement.
slide.text: Outcomes Secondary intervention after PTGBD Law R, et al. CGH 2016;14:476-480 32

slide.title: Outcomes
slide.text: Outcomes Alternative for malignant biliary obstruction instead of biliary drainage Itoi T, et al. Digest endosc 2013;25:137-141 33

slide.title: Outcomes
slide.text: Outcomes Alternative for malignant biliary obstruction instead of biliary drainage Imai H, et al. GIE 2016;84:147-151 34

slide.title: Contents
slide.text:
Contents Background Brief history Indications Techniques Outcomes Summary & conclusions
35

slide.title: Summary
slide.text:
Summary Strengths Excellent potential as an alternative of traditional drainage methods Technically feasible Safe, effective, and easy in expert hands Weakness Still too complex Not standardized Limited data with publication bias
36

slide.title: Conclusions
slide.text:
Conclusions EUS-GBD is a newly alternative to PTGBD or cholecystectomy
EUS-GBD is feasible and safe
More data and dedicated tools are necessary 37

slide.title: Thank You for Your Attention!
slide.text: 38 Thank You for Your Attention!
